content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" is introduced, which excludes space-related income from gross income according to a new section 139B in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" introduces a new section 139B in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, stating that gross income shall not include space-related income. Space-related income includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and certain interest, rent, or royalty amounts related to space activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" introduces a new section 139B in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, stating that gross income shall not include space-related income. This includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and certain interest, rent, or royalty amounts related to space activities. Exceptions are made for telecommunications services from earth orbit, services from weather or earth observation satellites, and transporting property to or from outer space. Wages received by employees are also exempt. Space-related income is proportionally allocated between space-based and earth-based activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code, stating that space-related income shall not be included in gross income. This includes products or services produced in outer space, with exemptions for certain activities like telecommunications services from earth orbit. Space-related income is proportionally allocated between space-based and earth-based activities. Products manufactured in outer space are exempt from Federal excises, imposts, and tariffs if launched from or manufactured at a facility owned by United States persons. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from gross income, including products manufactured in outer space. If launched from the US or manufactured at a facility owned by US persons, these products are exempt from Federal excises, imposts, and tariffs. The benefits phase out after December 31, 2014, reducing the exclusion amount based on the number of years after 2015. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from gross income and products manufactured in outer space from Federal taxes. Amendments apply to taxable years after December 31, 2005. Additionally, a new section, "SEC. 45J. SPACE COMPANY INVESTMENT CREDIT," provides a credit for the purchase of qualified space company stock. The "Space Company Investment Credit" allows for a credit on qualified stock purchases in a domestic C corporation with specific revenue and space-based business criteria. The credit is determined by the amount paid for qualified stock in a qualified space company. The term 'space-based business' refers to a business with gross receipts primarily from space-related income. Rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply for aggregation. Qualified stock in a domestic C corporation is defined as stock acquired from a qualified space company at its original issue in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services. During the taxpayer's holding period, qualified stock must be acquired from a qualified space company in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services. The corporation must meet active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) for a space-based business and be a C corporation. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply for certain purchases of its own stock. Recapture may occur within a 10-year period ending on the date of stock purchase. The tax credit for space company investments applies to qualified stock acquired from a qualified space company by a C corporation. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply for stock purchases. If the issuer ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years of stock purchase, the tax for that year increases. This provision does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2013. The credit is part of the general business credit under section 38(b) of the tax code. The tax credit for space company investments is part of the general business credit under section 38(b) of the tax code. Amendments are made to include the space company investment credit in the code. The amendments made by this section introduce the Space Company Investment Credit, effective for costs incurred after December 31, 2005. Additionally, a new section is added to the Internal Revenue Code allowing for an exclusion of gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code excludes gain on the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations. A qualified space corporation is a domestic C corporation organized for providing products or services in outer space, with at least 90% of expenses related to this business activity. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code excludes gain on the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2005.
